--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@c...> wrote:
> For modular NEAT, chromosome and module compatibility are computed
> similarly to how Ken does it with NEAT, but instead of keeping a 
fixed
> value for the species compatibility threshold, mine floats. 

As does the SCT when the number of species is fixed.  But it sounds 
like your approach alters the threshold based on the amount of 
topological variation in the population...is that right?

Populations with less variation have a smaller speciation threshold, 
and thus are more likely to be composed of similar species, while 
populations with more variation are more likely to be composed of 
species that are less like each other.

Wouldn't you get similar results by having a floating SCT value and a 
fixed number of species? 

The end result of your technique still seems to be stabilizing the 
number of species.

And you still have the same philosophical approach as clamping the 
number of species (i.e., what determines whether or not two 
individuals belong in the same species is not really how 
topologically similar or different they are, but some other attribute 
of the population...in this case, the level of variability).

Derek
